titleStmt.title: Description of University of Pennsylvania Oversize Ms. Codex 110: Alchemical miscellany

availability.licence: These images and the content of Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts Oversize Ms. Codex 110: Alchemical miscellany are free of known copyright restrictions and in the public domain. See the Creative Commons Public Domain Mark page for usage details, http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/mark/1.0/.

notesStmt.note: The edges of most folios are slightly torn and split. There is evidence of water and mildew damage. The last four folios are badly damaged, with loss of text; extensive repairs have been done on the paper.

Two autograph notes (front flyleaf ii recto): 1.) Haymon Styleman-le Strange, indicating that the manuscript was bound in October 1871; 2.) Falconer Mandan, dated 1 December 1892, identifying the first text.
Typescript table of contents included (front flyleaf i verso).
Forms part of: Edgar F. Smith Memorial Collection.

msIdentifier.repository: Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts

msContents.summary: Collection of four works concerning alchemy by Roger Bacon, Morienus Romanus (apocryphal), Geber (i.e., Jābir ibn Ḥayyān), and Avicenna. Includes an index to the volume that is incomplete and badly damaged.

msItem.title: Quaestiones inter Kalid regem et Morienum philosophum, f. 10r

support.watermark: Visible in gutter, but not legible enough for identification.

supportDesc.extent: 54 leaves : 298 x 196 (227 x 150) mm. bound to 306 x 207 mm

collation.p: Paper, ii (modern paper) + 50 + ii (modern paper); 1-3¹², 4¹⁶ (-2); 1-50; contemporary foliation in ink, with roman numerals preceded by quire letter (e.g., bxvii = f. 17, in quire 2), lower right recto, many trimmed away; modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto. Catchwords in lower margin, last verso of each quire.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Written in a Gothic cursive script, with marginalia written in various hands.

binding.p: Half morocco; England, 1871 (front flyleaf ii recto).

origin.p: Written in England[?] in the first half of the 15th century.

history.provenance: Hamon Styleman-le Strange (signature, flyleaf ii recto); Falconer Madan (signature, flyleaf ii recto); W. M. Voynich (Zacour-Hirsch).
